loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Mr. Rin S., 40, and his wife, Mrs. Sinoun Mao, 43, live along National Road Number One approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1996 and have one daughter who is attending school. Rin was not available for the photo so his wife is shown instead.
 
Rin has been a policeman for twenty years while his wife stays at home and does housework. He hopes to create a pig-raising business his wife; he will be able to earn more income from selling pigs when they grow big enough.

Therefore, Rin is asking for his first loan of $600 to use for this purpose.

Niavelle is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. texts.en:

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Jocelyn is married and has four school-aged children. She owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Jocelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. Jocelyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Kem

texts.en:

Presently he has a partner in his wife, who stays at home to plant a few vegetables to make a living. They have five children who are teenagers who are no longer in school but are employed.

Kem K. applies for a loan for his wife to buy more farming supplies for her business.

texts.en:
Karim Marzoev is from the region of Abdurahmon Jomi. He's forty-seven, married, and has five children. He has been in the livestock business for more than sixteen years, fattening up and selling cattle. He is trying to improve the quality of his cattle so they'll fetch a higher profit. He plans to use his loan to buy cattle.

Translated from Russian by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: So-Koeun

texts.en: Mrs. So-koeun, 32 and her husband, Mr. Socheata Hul, 40, live about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1997 and have two children, a son and a daughter, one attending school, while the other one is yet too young. So-koeun has been a tailor for four years, while her husband has been an electrician for ten years. She is now requesting her first loan in the amount of $600 to purchase another kind of sewing machine and fabric for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase another kind of sewing machine and fabric for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Cyprienne

texts.fr: Cyprienne est âgée de 53 ans, elle veuve et mère de 5 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de Sainte ANNE1 depuis 8 ans et a eu à y bénéficier de 16 prêts qu'elle a toujours remboursés régulièrement. Elle développe un petit commerce de citron, de miel, et d'huile de palme. Son objectif est de renforcer son épargne et de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Cyprienne is a 53 year-old widow with five children. She has been a member of the Sainte ANNE1 Village Bank for the past eight years and has been able to repay her 16 previous loans. She is expanding her small business that sells lemons, honey and palm oil. Her goal is to increase her savings and improve her children's living conditions.

Translated from French by Joanne Archambault, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand her revenue generating business

loans.name: Fatuma Adongo

texts.en: Fatuma, a 41-year-old married lady with five children, has been running a fish supply business for the last eight years.  She earns extra income  by running a retail shop. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to plan for her business, and she is now requesting a loan of Kes.20,000 to buy additional fish.  Fatuma describes herself as hardworking and determined as she works to establish a stable business for her family's needs.

loans.use: Purchase an additional stock of fish

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is a 42-year-old married woman with five children. 
She runs a general shop where she sells clothes, household items and food. She also makes dresses. She employs two people. Her other sources of income are rental houses and a water business. Previously she was a tailor. With the loan, Flora wants to buy sugar, flower, and more sewing materials. She hopes to have a stable business and family in the future and to open additional outlets. Flora describes herself as honest and determined.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, flower, and sewing materials.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap N., 47, and her husband, Mr. Saroeun Penh, 46, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.  They were married in 1980 and have one daughter who attends primary school. 

Sopheap has been a silk weaver for five years. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a marine for 35 years.  

Sopheap is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy cows to raise and also to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To buy cows and to buy silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 50 years old and married with five children between the ages 12 and 30, two of whom are still attending school. She's a dairy and tea farmer in the Nyamira area of Western Kenya and began farming two years ago, after retiring from her nursing profession. She sells her milk and tea within the local community and employs two people in her work. She says that the main challenges to her business are market conditions and the impact of the drought.

She requested this first loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 45,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says the added income from the loan will allow her to cater for her family's needs. In the future, Graces hopes to continue to improve her dairy farming so that she can better provide for her children.

About Juhudi Kilimo

Juhudi Kilimo is an innovative, for-profit social enterprise working with smallholder farmers in Kenya. Juhudi directly finances dairy cows, chickens, agricultural equipment, and other assets that are specifically chosen to create immediate cash flow. Many of the assets are insured to prevent devastating business losses, and targeted technical assistance is provided to farmers, from agricultural training to basic bookkeeping and local market research. For its clients and their families, Juhudi also offers life insurance and a medical aid program. Through all these services, Juhudi is creating sustainable growth and employment in rural communities across Kenya.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is a 32-year-old widow with two children who attend school.  She has been running a salon for four years and employs one person.  She appreciates Faulu Kenya for helping her business grow, which raises her family's living standard.  She hopes to open a wholesale beauty shop in the future.  She is requesting a loan to buy a steamer, hair products, and hair weaves.  She is very hardworking.

loans.use: Buy a steamer and hair products

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

She has been running her business for three years and wants to purchase more stock with the KES 80,000 loan. Previously, she was employed in a tailoring shop. She hopes to expand her business and to own personal properties someday. Maryanne describes herself as hardworking and friendly.

loans.name: Lilian Ayuma

She hopes to have a prosperous and stable family life in the future. Lilian also dreams of operating a wholesale chemist in the future. She describes herself as trustworthy, hardworking and honest.

He opened this small business to help his father with the family's income and to improve his economic situation. His mini-market is situated in a busy area. Because of the shop location, he has been able to have an increasing number of clients pass by his shop and buy all types of food products. Today, Farouk is requesting to borrow $800 to buy more merchandise so he can increase his sales and, therefore, his income.

loans.name: Elizabeth Makokha

texts.en: Elizabeth is 35 years old. She is married and has three children, who attend school. She has been a fish supplier for seven years. She employs two people. She was previously employed as a casual labourer. She earns extra income from the sales of household items. She plans to buy fish and omena (small fish) with a KES 20,000 loan. She hopes to have a stable family and business.  She dreams of running a well established company in the future.    She describes herself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To buy fish for resale.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a 49 year-old widow and mother of 3 children. With the help of her first loan, she managed to purchase accessories and cosmetic products to expand her business. She's very thankful for the loan because it allowed her to increase her income and in 2009 she was able to open a clothing shop in her town.

Today, Mariam is requesting to borrow $600 to expand her inventory and offer a bigger choice of clothes and collections to her clients.

loans.use: To expand her inventory

loans.name: Alie A.'s Group

texts.en:
Pictured are teachers from a primary school in Masomgbo village, one of the villages surrounding Makeni City. This school was established in 1950 to train children of the Masomgbo community, and villages close to it, as future leaders. Over the years, the school has produced a great number of lecturers, teachers, and other professionals in different walks of life. Currently, the school has 488 pupils and a staff of 13 teachers.

This is the second loan these teachers are accessing from Kiva through SMT. School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not be able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Fifty-seven-year-old Alie A. S. (left) is the headmaster at the school and has been a teacher for 36 years. He was born in Masomgbo village, and is married with ten children; some of his children are in primary school, some in secondary school, and others are in college. Alie will use his loan to pay his children's school fees. (Attached on the photo is a snapshot of 2 staff members who were not present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 32 year old married woman with one child who attends school. She has been operating Jane Salon for three years.  She offers hair and beauty services and employs three people. She also sells groceries for additional income.

With the loan, she hopes to purchase cosmetics for 5,000 KES and a blow dryer for 10,000 KES.  She is grateful to Faulu Kenya for teaching her to keep a record of her business. Jane describes herself as hardworking and determined.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and a blow dryer.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.use: buy new sewing machines and work equipment for his tailoring business.

loans.name: Komildjon

texts.ru: Узункулов Комилджон проживает в районе Восе. Возраст, 43 года. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Узункулов Комилджон имеет среднее образование. Животноводством занимается более 5 лет. Узункулов Комилджон разводит крупно- рогатый скот. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Komildjon U. lives in the Vose district. He is 43 years old, married and has 6 children. Komildjon has a secondary education. He has been involved in animal husbandry for over 5 years. Komildjon breeds cattle. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy merchandise for her food market

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy charcoal wholesale for resale.

loans.name: Sohkna

texts.fr:
Madame Sokhna Cissé est vendeuse de poissons fumés depuis 2 ans au marché khelkom sis à Thiès une ville située à 70 Kms de Dakar, la capitale du Sénégal. Ainsi, pour améliorer son petit commerce, elle sollicite un prêt de 50 000 FCFA pour profiter des affaires du Magal de Touba afin d’acheter des voiles, chaussures et autres produits qu’elle compte commercialiser à son retour de Touba.  Le Magal de Touba est une cérémonie religieuse commémorant le retour en exil de Cheikh Ahmadou Bamba, le pére fondateur du Mouridisme, une confrérie islamique.   Chaque année des milliers de pèlerins visitent le ville sacré. 
Mariée et mère de 6 enfants, cette femme d’un âge de 53 ans entend par cet acte diversifier ses ventes et développer son commerce.
texts.en:
For the past two years, Mrs. Sokhna Cissé has sold smoked fish at the Khelkom market in Thiès, a town located 70 kilometres from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. To improve her small business, she requests a loan of 50,000 FCFA to take advantage of opportunities surrounding the “Magal of Touba”, and buy veils, shoes and other products she will resell upon her return from Touba. The “Magal of Touba” is a religious ceremony commemorating the going into exile of Cheikh Ahmadou Bamba, the founding father of Mouridism, an Islamic brotherhood. Each year thousands of pilgrims visit the holy city. Married and mother of six children, this 53-year-old woman is taking an initiative to diversify her sales and develop her business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy veils, shoes, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Clothing sales

loans.name: Nadezhda

texts.en:
Nadezhda is an entrepreneur from Zaporozhye. She is a café owner. Her café is located in a nice quiet neighborhood of the city and is always full of people. Nadezhda opened her café 3 years ago. Within this short period of time she managed to establish a stable business with a good reputation among her customers. 

Nadezhda is a high-achiever. She always tries to be successful in all her endeavors. She is requesting a 15,000 Grivnya loan to increase her working capital which will allow her to improve service quality and diversify the menu in her café.  Nadezhda is very sociable. She has a friendly personality which helps her in her business.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Khadi

texts.fr: Madame Khadi T. née en 1965 s’active dans le commerce depuis 10 ans.  Elle a choisi ce métier pour dit elle subvenir  à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Après de bonnes années d’expérience, elle sentit la nécessité d’adhérer dans une mutuelle et c’est ainsi  qu’elle est devenue membre à U-IMCEC Thiès  en Août 2009. Cependant elle sollicita pour la première fois un crédit de 100 000 FCFA pour son approvisionnement afin de mieux fructifier son activité. Elle compte acheter avec ce financement du mil et d’autres produits pour la préparation du couscous.  Cette femme mariée et mère de 10 enfants est vendeuse ambulante de couscous  à Thiès.
texts.en:
Mrs. Khadi T., born in 1965, has been selling food for the past ten years. She chose this profession to meet her needs and those of her children. After useful years of experience, she felt the need to join a credit union, which is how she became a member of U-IMCEC Thiès in August 2009. She requested for the first time a loan of 100,000 FCFA, to replenish her supplies so she could grow her business. With the loan she will buy mil and other ingredients for the preparation of couscous. This married woman, mother of ten, is an itinerant couscous vendor in Thiès.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy mil (grain)

loans.name: Tecla

texts.en:
Tecla is a 22-year-old single mother of two children, ages three and five, who are both in school. She is a farmer near the town of Kitale in Western Kenya. She's been farming for four years and sells milk through Kenya Cooperative Creameries and maize cereals through the produce board. Before she began farming, she bought and sold eggs on a very small scale.

She has requested this first loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 35,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says she is building a bigger capital base so that she can be in a position to take out a larger loan next time. In the future, she'd like to own four pure-bred dairy cows that produce up to 20 litres each day. She also plans to buy a motor vehicle so that she can transport her milk and also buy and sell from the neighbors.

About Juhudi Kilimo

Juhudi Kilimo is an innovative, for-profit social enterprise working with smallholder farmers in Kenya. Juhudi directly finances dairy cows, chickens, agricultural equipment, and other assets that are specifically chosen to create immediate cash flow. Many of the assets are insured to prevent devastating business losses, and targeted technical assistance is provided to farmers, from agricultural training to basic bookkeeping and local market research. For its clients and their families, Juhudi also offers life insurance and a medical aid program. Through all these services, Juhudi is creating sustainable growth and employment in rural communities across Kenya.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Touré

texts.fr: Monsieur El Hadj M. Touré est un agent municipal depuis 1993 dans la ville de Dakar. Depuis 2 ans, il s’active parallèlement dans l’aviculture et gère son poulailler dans son quartier à Thiès une ville située à 70 Kms de Dakar. Marié et père de 8 enfants, Monsieur Touré est aidé dans son activité secondaire par les enfants. Ainsi il  souhaite obtenir un prêt de 150 000 FCFA dans U-IMCEC Thiès où il est membre depuis plus d’un an afin d’étendre son local et  de compléter son budget d’achat d’aliments de volaille. Pour cet homme âgé de 54 ans, ce crédit représente un véritable impact positif sur sa situation sociale car il pourra accroitre sa production et renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
Since 1993, Mr. Touré El Hadj M. has been a municipal agent in the city of Dakar. For the past two years, he has also taken an interest in aviculture and manages a henhouse in his neighbourhood in Thiès, a town located 70 kilometers from Dakar. Married and father of eight children, Mr. Touré is assisted in this activity by the children. He is requesting a loan for 150,000 FCFA from U-IMCEC Thiès, where he has been a member for over a year. He intends to expand the enclosure, and supplement his budget for purchasing chicken feed. This loan represents a truly positive impact on the social situation of this 54-year-old man, as he will be able to increase production and reinforce his activity.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy chicken feed

loans.name: Kana

texts.en:
Kana Y. is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a policeman. They have  5 children who go to school. Kana is currently in the business of selling charcoal at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua is fifty five years old. She is a divorcee with six children. She is really dedicated to her work and very supportive to all her children. Through her hard work, Comfort has supported her five of her children to complete school and has one still in school. She owns and operates clothing shop in the local market. She believes she can make her business grow bigger and brighter with loan support and wants to use the loan to buy more clothing materials to increase her stock of goods.

loans.use: To purchase assorted clothing.
